info-reveal.name: Google Gemini App Prompt
info-reveal.description: A tiny whisper of a carbon footprint: just 0.03 g of CO₂ per Gemini prompt. Blink and it’s gone.

info-reveal.name: Google Search
info-reveal.description: A single Google search spits out 0.2 grams of CO₂. So yes, asking “What time is it?” online leaves a trace of carbon footprint.

info-reveal.name: ChatGPT Prompt
info-reveal.description: Every prompt you send gives off 2 to 3 grams of CO₂. Small individually, but it adds up quickly while you chat nonstop!

info-reveal.name: Microwave Oven
info-reveal.description: Heating leftovers releases about 30 g of CO₂. Your microwave munchies come with a side of emissions.

info-reveal.name: Kettle
info-reveal.description: Boiling water emits about 47 grams of CO₂. Your tea time arrives with its own little carbon bill.

info-reveal.name: Disposable Coffee Cup
info-reveal.description: Your morning coffee takes about 50 g of CO₂. Energy, beans, and boiling water all leave their mark.

info-reveal.name: Generating a smaller model image using AI
info-reveal.description: Making a small AI image costs around 100 g of CO₂. That “quick” AI doodle isn’t as light as it looks.

info-reveal.name: Mobile Phone (1hr)
info-reveal.description: Using your phone for an hour means around 172 g of CO₂. That’s a lot for casual doom-scrolling.

info-reveal.name: Fridge-Freezer A spec
info-reveal.description: A fridge-freezer quietly hums out 175 g of CO₂ in a year. Keeping snacks cool still takes power.

info-reveal.name: Washing machine use
info-reveal.description: One load of laundry produces about 273 g of CO₂. Your clothes get clean; the planet gets a bit dirtier.

info-reveal.name: Car Ride
info-reveal.description: A short car ride burns through about 560 g of CO₂. Tiny trip, noticeable footprint.

info-reveal.name: Electric tumble dryer cycle
info-reveal.description: A tumble-dry cycle pumps out around 930 g of CO₂. Fluffy clothes come at a cost.

info-reveal.name: Toilet Paper
info-reveal.description: One toilet paper roll uses about 1,300 g of CO₂. Even wiping leaves a footprint.

info-reveal.name: Generating a bigger model image using AI
info-reveal.description: Generating a bigger AI image uses around 1,594 g of CO₂. A larger masterpiece comes with larger emissions.

info-reveal.name: Hot Shower
info-reveal.description: A hot 10-minute shower gives off about 2 kg of CO₂. Relaxing for you, not so much for the atmosphere.

info-reveal.name: Cooling
info-reveal.description: Cooling a typical U.S. home racks up roughly 2 kg of CO₂ each year. Comfort quietly consumes energy.

info-reveal.name: Heating
info-reveal.description: Heating a home hits about 7 kg of CO₂. Warm toes come with warming the planet.

info-reveal.name: GPT-3 daily carbon footprint
info-reveal.description: GPT-3 uses around 22.68 kg of CO₂ each day. AI conversation has a surprisingly hefty footprint.

info-reveal.name: Primary TV
info-reveal.description: Watching your primary TV for a year emits about 215 kg of CO₂. Binge-watching is far from carbon-free.

info-reveal.name: Kylie Jenner Private Jet Flight
info-reveal.description: Kylie Jenner’s 17-minute private-jet hop? A whole metric ton of CO₂. Yes, for 17 minutes.

info-reveal.name: Flight (Personal Footprint)
info-reveal.description: A flight from New York to Tokyo clocks in at 1.8 tons of CO₂. Crossing oceans leaves big footprints.

info-reveal.name: GPT-3 yearly carbon footprint
info-reveal.description: GPT-3’s yearly emissions reach around 7.62 tons of CO₂. Quite the appetite for electricity.

info-reveal.name: ChatGPT monthly carbon footprint
info-reveal.description: ChatGPT’s monthly footprint is about 260,930 kg of CO₂. Roughly the same as 160 transatlantic flights.

info-reveal.name: Training GPT-3
info-reveal.description: Training GPT-3 released about 502 tons of CO₂. A powerful model with a powerful footprint.

info-reveal.name: Training GPT-4
info-reveal.description: Training GPT-4 reached about 5,184 tons of CO₂. Building the future of AI takes a lot of energy.

info-reveal.name: Superyacht on Standby
info-reveal.description: Think of it as a gigantic luxury loaf just… waiting. Not sailing, not island-hopping, not even hosting a billionaire brunch. Just sitting there on standby — engines humming, generators purring — quietly exhaling 7,000 tonnes of CO₂ a year. That’s the carbon equivalent of lighting money on fire, except with more chrome, teak decks, and a helipad that definitely gets used less than advertised.

info-reveal.name: Taylor Swift Private Jet Flights
info-reveal.description: Taylor Swift’s flights in 2022 produced around 8,300 tons of CO₂. Sixteen days in the air leaves a massive trail.

info-reveal.name: Swiping on Dating Apps (Monthly)
info-reveal.description: All those lefts, rights, and “hey :)” messages add up — and not just emotionally. The top 10 dating apps in the U.S. collectively puff out about 9,614 tonnes of CO₂ every month. That’s right: modern romance now comes with a carbon footprint roughly the size of a small fleet of airplanes. Every swipe is technically a micro-emission, so if you’ve ever wondered why the planet feels a little warmer… well, it might be your situationships.

info-reveal.name: Doomscrolling on Tiktok
info-reveal.description: The annual carbon footprint of doom scrolling on tiktok for France, the UK, and the US add up to 75,169 tonnes of CO₂. Even actions you deem harmless have a negative environmental effects for mere moments of personal entertainment.

info-reveal.name: Uganda Electricity and Heat (2022)
info-reveal.description: Uganda carbon emission by electricty and heating in 2022 reached 130,000 tonnes. The price for our comfort is our environment.

info-reveal.name: Training Llama 3.1 (AI)
info-reveal.description: Training Llama 3.1 produced an astonishing 405 billion grams of CO₂. AI evolution comes with a serious environmental tab.

info-reveal.name: California Data Centers (2019-2023)
info-reveal.description: CO₂ emission generated by California Data Centers throughout 2019-2023 reached 9.42 million short tons, only increasing as time passes.

info-reveal.name: GenAI Global Emissions (Decade)
info-reveal.description: Generative AI could emit up to roughly 223 million tons of CO₂ over the next decade. The future footprint of AI is enormous if nothing changes.

info-reveal.name: Tobacco Industry
info-reveal.description: The tobacco industry produces roughly 84 million tons of CO₂ each year. From growing to smoking, it leaves a heavy mark.

info-reveal.name: UK Electricity and Heat (2022)
info-reveal.description: Electricity and heat in the UK during 2022 emitted around 91 illion tonnes of CO₂, continuing to increase throughout the years.

info-reveal.name: US Waste Emission (2022)
info-reveal.description: Waste in the U.S. during 2022 emitted 167 million tonnes of CO₂. The creation of waste damages our planet as does the disposal of it.

info-reveal.name: World Aviation and Shipping (2022)
info-reveal.description: The global carbon emission for aviation and shipping in 2022 reached 1.14 billion tonnes of  CO₂, threatening to increase and result in more environmental damage as economies develop.

info-reveal.name: Chinese Industrial Proccesses and Product Use
info-reveal.description: China’s industrial processes add over a billion tons of CO₂. Factory output echoes into the atmosphere.

info-reveal.name: World Waste Emission (2022)
info-reveal.description: Global carbon emission for waste in 2022 added up to arounf 1.90 billion tonnes. Waste continues to be a leading cause of carbon emissions worldwide.

info-reveal.name: Carbon Footprint of Data Centers (until 2030)
info-reveal.description: Data centers through 2030 may reach about 2.5 billion tons of CO₂. Our digital world runs on a giant carbon engine.

info-reveal.name: Manufacturing in the United States (2021)
info-reveal.description: U.S. manufacturing in 2021 emitted about 51.2 billion tons of CO₂. Industry keeps the planet working overtime.

fun-fact.p: By 2030, AI will be using the amount of energy that Japan uses today.
